titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Office of Reports, Office Files of Nancy Boggs
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Office of Reports, Office Files of Nancy Boggs FA1533

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-11-20 02:12:03 -0500.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Office of Reports, Office Files of Nancy Boggs

physdesc.extent: 9 Hollinger boxes and 1 3x5 card file box

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

When requesting to view audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916). Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact a RAC archivist for further instruction.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use". If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the users responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas. During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files, and officers' papers were transferred to and accessioned by the RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.
This material was transferred to the RAC in 2019 and was ingested by the RAC as Accession 2019:064.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collection contains the staff subject files of Nancy Boggs who worked as an Administrative Officer and Graphics Manager in the Ford Foundation's Office of Reports. Files contain correspondence, memos, drafts, scripts, notes, invoices, expense reports, inventories, contracts and agreements, schedules, newspaper clippings, and photographs that document Boggs work on the Foundation's sponsored films and other media projects. The records regard the promotion and distribution of the films as well as the production and planning of those movies. The films that the documents regard concerned subjects like primary healthcare, education, and jobs.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is comprised of one series.
Original order was maintained as much possible.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Nancy Boggs (1930-1994) worked as an Administrative Officer and Graphics Manager in the Ford Foundation's Office of Reports. She played a critical role in the advancement of the Foundation's use of film and television media to promote its activities.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: A significant amount of content within the collection regards the Ford Foundation sponsored film "That Our Children Will Not Die". The film is available in FA750 Ford Foundation records, Audiovisual materials

did.unittitle: Subject files

physdesc.extent: 6 LTR size Hollinger boxes, 3 LGL size Hollinger boxes, and 1 3x5 card file box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains the subject files that Nancy Boggs created during her time as an Administrative Officer and Graphics Manager in the Ford Foundation's Office of Reports. The bulk of the records regard Boggs' work supporting the planning, production, promotion, and distribution of the Foundation's various sponsored films. Boggs' work on the Institute of Child Health (ICH) film "That Our Children Will Not Die" is particularly well documented in the series, but there are also records concerning films like "Changing Work", "They Call It Wildcat", and "Tomorrow We'll See What Happens" among others. These films chiefly regard topics like primary health care, education, and jobs and job programs. Correspondence, memos, notes, Recommended Grant Actions records (RGAs), contracts and agreements, invoices, and expense reports document how Boggs worked with consultant producers, directors, and film crews and co-sponsor institutions like the ICH in the planning and production of the different films. Similar materials as well as newspaper clippings, drafts, photographs, and inventories document how Boggs assisted the promotion and dissemination of the films.
The remaining files in the series regard the Office of Reports' promotion of other Ford Foundation activities and the use of television and film media in that kind of promotion.

did.unittitle: That Our Children Will Not Die film - Transcript and translations
did.langmaterial: There are English, Portuguese, and French versions of the film's transcript in the file.

Ford Foundation films - Stills and negatives
did.physdesc: File is mainly comprised of still images. These images include film stills and a film negative.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The film negative and several of the stills in the file are from the Ford Foundation sponsored film "Changing Work". These images are interspersed with a group of stills from the "Household Technicians" episode of the "Are You Listening" series along with correspondence from Martha Stuart Communications to Nancy Boggs. It is unclear why these two groups of unrelated images were mixed together. The file also contains a set of stills related to the Institute of Child Health (ICH), University of Lagos film "That Our Children Will Not Die". A document describing these photographs is included. Photograph 6 in the set appears to be missing from the file.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The still image in the file is a photograph depicting two students. The photograph is mostly likely related to the "Tomorrow We'll See What Happens" film about the Tutorial Community Project (TCP).

did.unittitle: Changing Work film
did.physdesc: File includes a set of still images.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photograph negatives in the file are stills from the Ford Foundation sponsored film "Changing Work". Those images would be used in the Foundation's report "A Work Experiment: Six Americans in a Swedish Plant" about the Detroit-Sweden worker exchange program the film concerns.
